The **Newfoundland and Labrador New Democratic Party** (**NL NDP**) is a
[social democratic](/wiki/Social_democracy "Social democracy") political party
in [Newfoundland and Labrador](/wiki/Newfoundland_and_Labrador "Newfoundland
and Labrador"), [Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada"). It is a provincial section of
the federal [New Democratic Party](/wiki/New_Democratic_Party_\(Canada\) "New
Democratic Party \(Canada\)"). It was formed in 1961 as the successor to the
[Co-operative Commonwealth Federation](/wiki/Co-
operative_Commonwealth_Federation "Co-operative Commonwealth Federation")
(CCF) and the Newfoundland Democratic Party. The party first contested the
[1962 provincial election](/wiki/Newfoundland_general_election,_1962
"Newfoundland general election, 1962").

[Lorraine Michael](/wiki/Lorraine_Michael "Lorraine Michael") was elected
leader of the NL NDP at the [party's leadership
election](/wiki/New_Democratic_Party_of_Newfoundland_and_Labrador_leadership_election,_2006
"New Democratic Party of Newfoundland and Labrador leadership election, 2006")
on May 28, 2006. She led the party during the
[2007](/wiki/Newfoundland_and_Labrador_general_election,_2007 "Newfoundland
and Labrador general election, 2007") and
[2011](/wiki/Newfoundland_and_Labrador_general_election,_2011 "Newfoundland
and Labrador general election, 2011") general elections, each time improving
the party's share of vote from the previous election. In the 2011 election a
record five NDP MHAs were elected under her leadership.[2] Michael was
[succeeded](/wiki/New_Democratic_Party_of_Newfoundland_and_Labrador_leadership_election,_2015
"New Democratic Party of Newfoundland and Labrador leadership election, 2015")
by former [Fish, Food and Allied Workers
Union](/wiki/Fish,_Food_and_Allied_Workers_Union "Fish, Food and Allied
Workers Union") president, [Earle McCurdy](/wiki/Earle_McCurdy "Earle
McCurdy") on March 7, 2015.

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Newfoundland_and_Labrador_New_Democratic_Party&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

###
Founding[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Newfoundland_and_Labrador_New_Democratic_Party&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Founding")]

The NL NDP is the successor party to the [Co-operative Commonwealth
Federation](/wiki/Co-operative_Commonwealth_Federation "Co-operative
Commonwealth Federation") (CCF). The Newfoundland CCF was founded in 1955 when
[Sam Drover](/wiki/Sam_Drover "Sam Drover"), a member of the [Newfoundland
House of Assembly](/wiki/Newfoundland_and_Labrador_House_of_Assembly
"Newfoundland and Labrador House of Assembly") for [White
Bay](/wiki/White_Bay_\(Newfoundland_and_Labrador\) "White Bay \(Newfoundland
and Labrador\)") (Trinity North) who left the provincial [Liberal
Party](/wiki/Liberal_Party_of_Newfoundland_and_Labrador "Liberal Party of
Newfoundland and Labrador") to sit as a member of the CCF. Drover became
leader of the new provincial party, which fielded ten candidates, mostly in
rural districts, in the [1956 provincial
election](/wiki/Newfoundland_general_election,_1956 "Newfoundland general
election, 1956"). The CCF party failed to win any seats: Drover lost his own
riding, winning 237 votes to the Liberal candidate's 1,437.[3]

The CCF did not run candidates in the 1959 election, but supported the
**Newfoundland Democratic Party**. This party had been organised by the
[Newfoundland Federation of Labour](/wiki/Newfoundland_Federation_of_Labour
"Newfoundland Federation of Labour") with the support of the [Canadian Labour
Congress](/wiki/Canadian_Labour_Congress "Canadian Labour Congress"), to
protest the Liberal government's decertification of the [International
Woodworkers of America](/wiki/International_Woodworkers_of_America
"International Woodworkers of America") in the course of a logging
[strike](/wiki/Strike_action "Strike action"). The Newfoundland Democratic
Party ran eighteen candidates, none of whom was elected. The party was led by
[Ed Finn, Jr.](/wiki/Ed_Finn,_Jr. "Ed Finn, Jr.") and [Calvin
Normore](/w/index.php?title=Calvin_Normore_\(politician\)&action=edit&redlink=1
"Calvin Normore \(politician\) \(page does not exist\)"). In 1961, the federal
[New Democratic Party](/wiki/New_Democratic_Party_\(Canada\) "New Democratic
Party \(Canada\)") was founded in with the merger of the federal CCF and the
[Canadian Labour Congress](/wiki/Canadian_Labour_Congress "Canadian Labour
Congress"). The Newfoundland Democratic Party followed suit becoming the
Newfoundland New Democratic Party with Finn leading the NL NDP into the [1962
provincial election](/wiki/Newfoundland_general_election,_1962 "Newfoundland
general election, 1962") and Normore doing so in
[1966](/wiki/Newfoundland_general_election,_1966 "Newfoundland general
election, 1966").[3]

###
1962–1984[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Newfoundland_and_Labrador_New_Democratic_Party&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: 1962–1984")]

Since the 1962 general election, the party has run candidates in all of
[Newfoundland and Labrador's general
elections](/wiki/List_of_Newfoundland_and_Labrador_general_elections "List of
Newfoundland and Labrador general elections"). From 1962 to 1984 the party was
led by seven different leaders and contested seven provincial elections. The
party won an average of 3.3% of the vote in those elections and were unable to
elect a candidate to the [Newfoundland and Labrador House of
Assembly](/wiki/Newfoundland_and_Labrador_House_of_Assembly "Newfoundland and
Labrador House of Assembly").

### Peter Fenwick
years[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Newfoundland_and_Labrador_New_Democratic_Party&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Peter Fenwick years")]

[Peter Fenwick](/wiki/Peter_Fenwick_\(politician\) "Peter Fenwick
\(politician\)") succeeded [Fonse Faour](/wiki/Fonse_Faour "Fonse Faour") as
party leader in 1981. In a 1984 [by-election](/wiki/By-election "By-
election"), Fenwick won the [Labrador](/wiki/Labrador "Labrador") riding of
[Menihek](/wiki/Labrador_West_\(electoral_district\) "Labrador West
\(electoral district\)") becoming the first New Democrat to be elected in the
province. In the [1985 general
election](/wiki/Newfoundland_general_election,_1985 "Newfoundland general
election, 1985") the party won 14 per cent of the popular vote, nearly
quadrupling their share of the vote they received three years earlier. Even
with their successful results Fenwick was the only NL NDP candidate
elected.[4][5] In 1986, [Gene Long](/wiki/Gene_Long "Gene Long") won the
party's second seat in a by-election in the riding of [St. John's
East](/wiki/St._John%27s_East_\(provincial_electoral_district\) "St. John's
East \(provincial electoral district\)") (since renamed [Signal Hill-Quidi
Vidi](/wiki/Signal_Hill-Quidi_Vidi "Signal Hill-Quidi Vidi")). Also that year
Fenwick was arrested, along with union representatives, for participating in a
strike by the Newfoundland Association of Public Employees (NAPE). Fenwick
retired from politics in 1989 and did not run in [that year's
election](/wiki/Newfoundland_general_election,_1989 "Newfoundland general
election, 1989"). [Cle Newhook](/wiki/Cle_Newhook "Cle Newhook") replaced
Fenwick as party leader and the NL NDP was once again left without
representation after the 1989 election when both ridings they had held were
won by [Progressive
Conservatives](/wiki/Progressive_Conservative_Party_of_Newfoundland_and_Labrador
"Progressive Conservative Party of Newfoundland and Labrador").

### Jack Harris
years[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Newfoundland_and_Labrador_New_Democratic_Party&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Jack Harris years")]

St. John's lawyer and former [Member of Parliament](/wiki/Member_of_Parliament
"Member of Parliament") [Jack
Harris](/wiki/Jack_Harris_\(Newfoundland_and_Labrador_politician\) "Jack
Harris \(Newfoundland and Labrador politician\)") won back the riding of [St.
John's East](/wiki/Signal_Hill-Quidi_Vidi "Signal Hill-Quidi Vidi") in a 1990
by-election after Progressive Conservative MHA [Shannie
Duff](/wiki/Shannie_Duff "Shannie Duff") resigned to run for Mayor. Harris
took nearly 50% of the vote in the by-election beating the Liberal candidate
by 740 votes. In 1992, Harris succeed Newhook as party leader and led the
party into the [1993 general
election](/wiki/Newfoundland_general_election,_1993 "Newfoundland general
election, 1993"). For the first and only time in the party's history they ran
a full slate of candidates throughout the province, while they won almost
10,000 more votes than the previous election and increased their share of the
popular vote from 3.4% to 7.4% Harris remained the only New Democrat elected.
The [1996 general election](/wiki/Newfoundland_general_election,_1996
"Newfoundland general election, 1996") resulted in a landslide majority
government for the [Liberal
Party](/wiki/Liberal_Party_of_Newfoundland_and_Labrador "Liberal Party of
Newfoundland and Labrador"), the New Democrats received only 4.45% of the vote
and nominated candidates in only 20 of the provinces 48 ridings. Though the
party suffered their worst electoral result in 14 years Harris was easily re-
elected in the new riding of [Signal Hill-Quidi Vidi](/wiki/Signal_Hill-
Quidi_Vidi "Signal Hill-Quidi Vidi").

### Lorraine
Michael[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Newfoundland_and_Labrador_New_Democratic_Party&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Lorraine Michael")]

Lorraine Michael [won the leadership of the Newfoundland and Labrador
NDP](/wiki/New_Democratic_Party_of_Newfoundland_and_Labrador_leadership_election,_2006
"New Democratic Party of Newfoundland and Labrador leadership election, 2006")
in 2006. After succeeding Harris as leader she was elected in his former
district of Signal Hill-Quidi Vidi several months later. In the [2007
provincial election](/wiki/Newfoundland_and_Labrador_general_election,_2007
"Newfoundland and Labrador general election, 2007") Michael was the only New
Democrat elected, though she increased her party's share of the popular vote.
Between 2007 and 2011 polling for the NL NDP remained below 10 per cent in
public opinion polls behind the Liberal Party and governing Progressive
Conservatives. However, after the federal New Democrat's success in the [2011
federal election](/wiki/Canadian_federal_election,_2011 "Canadian federal
election, 2011"), where they formed the official opposition, support for
Michael's New Democrats saw a surge in support. In a Corporate Research
Associates (CRA) poll conducted just weeks after the federal election in May
2011, the NL NDP support rose to 20 per cent. For the first time in its
history the party was statistically tied for second place with the [Liberal
Party](/wiki/Liberal_Party_of_Newfoundland_and_Labrador "Liberal Party of
Newfoundland and Labrador"), who were at 22 per cent. The New Democrats' gains
came at the expense of the governing Progressive Conservatives who fell to 57
per cent.[6] The NL NDP surpassed the Liberals in polling in September 2011,
and won just under 25 per cent of the popular vote, and five seats, in the
[October 11, 2011, general
election](/wiki/Newfoundland_and_Labrador_general_election,_2011 "Newfoundland
and Labrador general election, 2011"). The Progressive Conservatives won their
third straight majority government and while the New Democrats placed second
in the popular vote, they finished third behind the Liberal Party in seats.[7]

On October 21, 2013, it was revealed that Michael had received a letter from
her caucus over the previous weekend calling for a leadership election to be
held in 2014. The caucus felt that without renewal in the party they would
have trouble attracting quality candidates and public support in the 2015
election. In an interview with the [Canadian Broadcasting
Corporation](/wiki/Canadian_Broadcasting_Corporation "Canadian Broadcasting
Corporation") (CBC), Michael said she was shocked by the letter and felt
betrayed by her caucus. Michael said she planned to sit down with her caucus
before making a decision on what to do.[8]

The letter led to a public fight within the NDP, particularly among the
caucus. Both [Gerry Rogers](/wiki/Gerry_Rogers "Gerry Rogers") and [George
Murphy](/wiki/George_Murphy_\(Canadian_politician\) "George Murphy \(Canadian
politician\)") said they regretted sending the letter and supported Michael,
while [Dale Kirby](/wiki/Dale_Kirby "Dale Kirby") and [Chris
Mitchelmore](/wiki/Chris_Mitchelmore "Chris Mitchelmore") stood behind what
they had written in the letter. Following the caucus meeting Michael agreed to
having a vote on her leadership at the next annual general meeting of the
party. Both Kirby and Mitchelmore later announced they were leaving the caucus
to sit as Independent MHAs, and both men joined the Liberal Party in February
2014. The dispute over Michael's leadership also led to members of the
provincial executive to resign.[9][10][11] In May 2014 a party convention
reaffirmed her leadership with the support of 75% of delegates. Michael
announced on January 6, 2015, that she would step down as leader after the
party performed poorly in four recent by-elections. While she was resigning as
leader Michael also stated that she planned to seek re-election as an MHA.[12]
Her term as leader ended when her successor was chosen in a leadership
election held on March 7, 2015.[13]

### Earle
McCurdy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Newfoundland_and_Labrador_New_Democratic_Party&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Earle McCurdy")]

Main article: [New Democratic Party of Newfoundland and Labrador leadership
election,
2015](/wiki/New_Democratic_Party_of_Newfoundland_and_Labrador_leadership_election,_2015
"New Democratic Party of Newfoundland and Labrador leadership election, 2015")

Three candidates sought to succeed Michael as leader: former [Fish, Food and
Allied Workers Union](/wiki/Fish,_Food_and_Allied_Workers_Union "Fish, Food
and Allied Workers Union") leader [Earle McCurdy](/wiki/Earle_McCurdy "Earle
McCurdy"), former [Labrador City](/wiki/Labrador_City "Labrador City") town
councillor Mike Goosney and former NDP official Chris Bruce[14][15]

McCurdy won the election with 68 percent of the vote on March 7, 2015. He did
not win his seat in the 2015 provincial election. Therefore, Michael
subsequently served as NDP House Leader in the following parliamentary
sessions.

On September 19, 2017, McCurdy announced his resignation as Leader, effective
September 30, 2017.[16]

## Party
policies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Newfoundland_and_Labrador_New_Democratic_Party&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Party policies")]

The New Democratic Party in Newfoundland and Labrador has long been a party
that has advocated [social democratic](/wiki/Social_democracy "Social
democracy") policies that support working people and families and the labour
movement. On September 20, 2007, the party released its policy platform for
the 2007 general election. The platform's main points were:

  * A review of the province's health care system;
  * A universal [pharmacare](/wiki/Pharmaceutical_policy "Pharmaceutical policy") program;
  * Safe, healthy, and clean neighbourhood schools;
  * A home care and home support program for seniors;
  * A better energy plan than the one created by the [Williams](/wiki/Danny_Williams_\(politician\) "Danny Williams \(politician\)") government;
  * Increased funding for women's centres and initiatives;
  * A province-wide 911 system;
  * [Anti-Scab](/wiki/Strike_action "Strike action") legislation; and
  * Free tuition for public post-secondary education.

### Historical
representation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Newfoundland_and_Labrador_New_Democratic_Party&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Historical representation")]

The New Democratic Party won its first seat in the House of Assembly in 1984
when leader Peter Fenwick was elected in a by-election for the district of
Labrador West. The party has been represented in the provincial legislature
continually since 1990. Former leader and St. John's East Member of Parliament
Jack Harris was elected to represent the district in the 1990, 1993, 1996,
1999 and 2003 provincial elections. Signal Hill-Quidi Vidi has been
represented in the House of Assembly by party leader Lorraine Michael since
2006.

  * [Sam Drover](/wiki/Sam_Drover "Sam Drover"), MHA for White Bay, 1955-1956 CCF (Drover crossed the floor from the Liberals),
  * [Peter Fenwick](/wiki/Peter_Fenwick_\(politician\) "Peter Fenwick \(politician\)"), MHA for Menihek (Labrador West), 1984–1985, 1985–1989
  * [Gene Long](/wiki/Gene_Long "Gene Long"), MHA for St. John's East, 1986–1989
  * [Jack Harris](/wiki/Jack_Harris_\(Newfoundland_and_Labrador_politician\) "Jack Harris \(Newfoundland and Labrador politician\)"), MHA for St. John's East, 1990 (by-election)-1995, Signal Hill-Quidi Vidi 1995-2006
  * [Randy Collins](/wiki/Randy_Collins "Randy Collins") MHA for Labrador West, 1999–2007
  * [Lorraine Michael](/wiki/Lorraine_Michael "Lorraine Michael"), MHA for Signal Hill-Quidi Vidi, 2006–2015; St. John's East-Quidi Vidi, 2015-Present
  * [Dale Kirby](/wiki/Dale_Kirby "Dale Kirby"), MHA for St. John's North, 2011-2013
  * [Christopher Mitchelmore](/wiki/Christopher_Mitchelmore "Christopher Mitchelmore"), MHA for The Straits-White Bay North, 2011-2013
  * [George Murphy](/wiki/George_Murphy_\(Canadian_politician\) "George Murphy \(Canadian politician\)"), MHA for St. John's East, 2011–2015
  * [Gerry Rogers](/wiki/Gerry_Rogers "Gerry Rogers"), MHA for St. John's Centre, 2011–Present

## Relationship with the federal
party[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Newfoundland_and_Labrador_New_Democratic_Party&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Relationship with the federal party")]

The NL NDP is affiliated with the federal [New Democratic
Party](/wiki/New_Democratic_Party_\(Canada\) "New Democratic Party
\(Canada\)"). Two of the three New Democratic Party Members of Parliament ever
elected to the [Canadian House of Commons](/wiki/House_of_Commons_of_Canada
"House of Commons of Canada") from Newfoundland and Labrador went on to lead
the provincial party:

  * Fonse Faour, who won a by-election in 1978 in the federal riding of [Humber—St. George's—St. Barbe](/wiki/Humber%E2%80%94St._George%27s%E2%80%94St._Barbe "Humber—St. George's—St. Barbe"), and was re-elected the following year in the [1979 federal election](/wiki/Canadian_federal_election,_1979 "Canadian federal election, 1979") in the renamed riding of [Humber—Port au Port—St. Barbe](/wiki/Humber%E2%80%94Port_au_Port%E2%80%94St._Barbe "Humber—Port au Port—St. Barbe"). Faour was defeated in the subsequent [1980 federal election](/wiki/Canadian_federal_election,_1980 "Canadian federal election, 1980"). He then went on to serve as leader of the provincial party.
  * Jack Harris, won a 1987 by-election in the riding of [St. John's East](/wiki/St._John%27s_East "St. John's East"), but was defeated the following year in the [1988 federal election](/wiki/Canadian_federal_election,_1988 "Canadian federal election, 1988"). Harris served as leader of the provincial party before being re-elected to represent St. John's East in the [2008 federal election](/wiki/Canadian_federal_election,_2008 "Canadian federal election, 2008").

##
Leaders[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Newfoundland_and_Labrador_New_Democratic_Party&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Leaders")]

  * [Sam Drover](/wiki/Sam_Drover "Sam Drover"), 1955–1956. Although not elected as leader of the party, Samuel Drover effectively led the NL NDP's predecessor party, the CCF, in the 1956 provincial election. In 1955, Drover had crossed the floor from the Liberal Party to sit in the opposition as a CCF MHA.
  * [Ed Finn, Jr.](/wiki/Ed_Finn,_Jr. "Ed Finn, Jr."), 1959–1963. Ed Finn became co-leader of the Newfoundland Democratic Party upon its inception in 1959, and assumed the leadership of the CCF and the New Democratic Party. Finn narrowly lost his bid for a seat in the House of Assembly in the 1962 provincial election when he ran for the NL NDP in Humber West. He left Newfoundland and Labrador in 1963 to pursue a career as a labour researcher, writer, and journalist.
  * [Calvin George Normore](/w/index.php?title=Calvin_George_Normore&action=edit&redlink=1 "Calvin George Normore \(page does not exist\)"), 1963—1966, led the party during the 1966 provincial election. Head of the Corner Brook Labor Council and vice-president of the Newfoundland Federation of Labour, he had been co-leader of the Newfoundland Democratic Party in 1959.
  * [Esau Thoms](/w/index.php?title=Esau_Thoms&action=edit&redlink=1 "Esau Thoms \(page does not exist\)"), 1966–1970. A founding member of the Newfoundland Democratic Party in the late 1950s and one of the province's foremost labour organizers, Esau Thoms had contested two federal elections for the CCF. From 1966 to 1970, the Newfoundland and Labrador New Democratic Party was without a formal leader, relying instead upon local committees throughout the province, but Thoms was essentially de facto leader. He was a consistently outspoken voice for social democracy and social justice until his death in 1979.
  * [John Connors](/w/index.php?title=John_Connors_\(politician\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "John Connors \(politician\) \(page does not exist\)"), 1970–1974. John Connors took the reins of the party in 1970 at a difficult time, as the electorate became sharply divided over whether to continue supporting the Liberal Party. Connors was a candidate for the NL NDP in the 1968 federal election, and was one of only three NL NDP candidates in the 1972 provincial campaign. He later pursued a career at the Marine Institute.
  * [Gerry Panting](/wiki/Gerry_Panting "Gerry Panting"), 1974–1977. Gerald Panting led the party from 1974 to 1977. Panting was a distinguished historian and founder of the Maritime History Group at Memorial University of Newfoundland. He ran for the NL NDP provincially five times, coming in a strong second in the 1975 general election. A dedicated party builder, Panting remained active within the NL NDP until his death in 1998.
  * [John Green](/wiki/John_Green_\(politician\) "John Green \(politician\)"), 1977–1980. John Greene led the NL NDP from 1977 to 1980 and played a significant role in building the party. He came close to winning a seat in the House of Assembly, giving a strong showing in the televised leaders debate. Due to his leadership the NL NDP became a recognized provincial party. This helped set the stage for the party's later electoral success. Greene later became an author and remained active in various human rights organizations.
  * [Fonse Faour](/wiki/Fonse_Faour "Fonse Faour"), 1980–1981. Fonse Faour served a one-year term a leader from 1980 to 1981 after serving as the party's first Member of Parliament from Newfoundland and Labrador in the House of Commons. He was elected as an MP in 1978 and 1979, and was defeated in the 1980 general election. Faour later worked in senior positions with the provincial public service and served as Chairperson and Chief Executive Officer of the Public Service Commission. In 2003, Faour was appointed to the trial division of the Newfoundland and Labrador Supreme Court.
  * [Peter Fenwick](/wiki/Peter_Fenwick_\(politician\) "Peter Fenwick \(politician\)"), 1981–1989. Leader from 1981 to 1989, in 1984 Fenwick set a landmark in provincial history by becoming the first New Democrat to be elected to the House of Assembly, sitting as the member for the former Labrador district of Menihek. He was re-elected in 1985. An outspoken leader, he was jailed in 1986 along with union representatives who participated in a strike by the Newfoundland Association of Public Employees.
  * [Cle Newhook](/wiki/Cle_Newhook "Cle Newhook") 1989–1992. Cle Newhook served as party leader from 1989 to 1992 after working full-time as the party's provincial secretary from 1986 to 1988. As a candidate in several elections, and through work as leader and provincial secretary, he played a major role in the party's development throughout the 1980s and early 1990s. Newhook now works as a consultant in St. John's.
  * [Jack Harris](/wiki/Jack_Harris_\(Newfoundland_and_Labrador_politician\) "Jack Harris \(Newfoundland and Labrador politician\)"), 1992–2006. First elected as Member of Parliament for St. John's East in 1987, he was elected to the Newfoundland and Labrador House of Assembly in the 1990 provincial election and was acclaimed leader of the NL NDP in 1992. He was re-elected to the Legislature in the 1993, 1996, 1999 and 2003 elections. In October 2008, Harris was a second time elected Member of Parliament for the riding of St. John's East receiving 74.1% of the vote—the fifth-highest winning percentage in Canada.
  * [Lorraine Michael](/wiki/Lorraine_Michael "Lorraine Michael"), 2006–2015. Upon winning the NL NDP leadership election in May 2006, Michael later won the by-election for Signal Hill-Quidi Vidi in November of that year. She was re-elected in her riding in the 2007 general election, and in the 2011 election a record five NDP MHAs were elected by the voters.[2] She was re-elected in 2015.
  * [Earle McCurdy](/wiki/Earle_McCurdy "Earle McCurdy"), 2015—present. McCurdy won the leadership in 2015. He had been president of the [Fish, Food and Allied Workers Union](/wiki/Fish,_Food_and_Allied_Workers_Union "Fish, Food and Allied Workers Union") from 1993 to 2014.[17]
